answers.answer: Fungal infections and diabetes go hand in hand unfortunately :(At this point it's best for you to follow up on this with a dermatologist since otc creams and oral diflucan aren't working for you.  They can best help you at this point.I also recommend returning to your doctor or seeing an urologist too because a run of the mill fungal infection, is not going to be so painful that you can't even move. You need to make sure that nothing else is going on too. It shouldn't be causing you pain in the genital area like this.grace

question: I have what my doctor calls a "yeast infection", but I gather there are different varieties.  I am Type 2 diabetic, 59 y.o.  I've had the infection for over a year.  It has been _extremely_ painful - some times more than others, sometimes also very itchy.   Since I've gotten my BG under control it's lessened but never gone away.  Doctor gave me an antifungal ointment last year which does nothing.  I took a fluconozole tablet once last year and it worked well but the infection returned.  Subsequent administration of fluconozole had no effect at all, so I gather the infection has developed a tolerance to it.I have to get rid of this...it is extremely painful to the point where I sometimes can't even move - I had had a quite active sex life,but can't do anything now even with a condom because of the pain.  Please. what more can I suggest to my doctor?
title: Penile fungus?
